bestBHT.bht: When Paul arrived in Tyre, he diligently searched for the disciples he had previously preached to, finding them and staying with them for seven days. These disciples, speaking through the Spirit, warned Paul not to go up to Jerusalem, foretelling the afflictions that awaited him there. However, duty called louder than the warning, and Paul's unwavering determination to fulfill his mission prevailed. Even though the prophetic impulse of the disciples suggested that Paul could avoid danger by not going, he chose to press on, steadfast in his resolve.

Henry Alford: 'Finding disciples' (A. V.) is quite wrong. It is not improbable that Paul may have preached at Tyre before,... 'the disciples' seems to imply this.

The notice here is very important, that these Tyrian disciples said to St. Paul by the Spirit, that he should not go to Jerusalem,—and yet he went thither, and, as he himself declares, bound in spirit by the leading of God.

We thus have an instance of that which Paul asserts 1 Cor. xiv. 32, that the spirits of prophets are subject to prophets, i.e. that the revelation made by the Holy Spirit to each man’s spirit was under the influence of that man’s will and temperament, moulded by and taking the form of his own capacities and resolves.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: finding disciples—finding out the disciples, implying some search. They would expect such, from what is recorded, Acts 11:19.
Perhaps they were not many; yet there were gifted ones among them.
who said to Paul . . . that he should not go up to Jerusalem—(See on Acts 11:19- :; also see on Acts 11:19- :).
Albert Barnes: It was not understood by Paul as a positive command that he should not go up to Jerusalem; for had it been, it would not have been disobeyed.

The meaning evidently is that they said by inspiration of the Spirit that he should not go unless he was willing to encounter danger, for they foresaw that the journey would be attended with the hazard of his life.
Paul was simply apprised of the danger, and was then left to the free determination of his own will. He chose to encounter the danger of which he was thus apprised.
Marvin Vincent: Finding disciples [ανευροντες τους μαθητας]. The verb means to discover after search; and the article, the disciples, refers to the disciples who lived and were recognized members of the church there."
The A. V. overlooks both the preposition and the article.
The verb might be rendered strictly by our common phrase, 'having looked up the disciples.'
John Calvin: Those alone are numbered in the flock of Christ who have embraced his doctrine by faith.
Surely this was no small temptation to cause him not to finish the journey which he had taken in hand, seeing the Holy Ghost did dissuade him from the same.

The Lord would have his servant admonished of purpose, partly, that through long meditation, he might be better furnished and prepared to suffer whatsoever should come, partly that his constancy might more plainly appear.
Philip Schaff: There were disciples who lived at Tyre, these were searched out by Paul and his companions.

St. Paul arranged to stay at each of these points where there was a Christian church... for the purpose of attending one solemn meeting of the brethren on the Lord’s day, and partaking once at least with them all of the Lord’s Supper.

Paul listened to the warning words, but convinced that the work which his Master wished him to do called him to Jerusalem, set his face steadily towards the city, regardless of all danger and suffering.
Archibald T. Robertson: Paul's indefatigible energy shows itself with characteristic zeal."
The Holy Spirit undoubtedly who had already told Paul that bonds and afflictions awaited him in Jerusalem."
Duty called louder than warning to Paul even if both were the calls of God.
John Gill: in this age Paulinus and Dorotheus were bishops of Tyre
the sense is, that these disciples, by the spirit of prophecy, knew that if the apostle went to Jerusalem, many evil things would befall him
these disciples...advise him not to go
John Wesley: And finding disciples, we tarried there seven days — ln order to spend a Sabbath with them.
Who told Paul by the Spirit — That afflictions awaited him at Jerusalem.
The disciples seemed to understand their prophetic impulse to be an intimation from the Spirit, that Paul, if he were so minded, might avoid the danger, by not going to Jerusalem.

bhtAttempts.bht: When Paul arrived in Tyre, he sought out the disciples and found them, which implies that he may have preached there before. These disciples warned Paul, through the leading of the Spirit, not to go to Jerusalem due to the impending dangers. However, Paul, bound in spirit by the leading of God, chose to continue on his journey despite the warning. This exemplifies Paul's assertion that the spirits of prophets are subject to prophets. Though duty called louder than the warning, Paul's unwavering resolve and determination to fulfill his mission in Jerusalem prevailed, even in the face of potential afflictions.

When Paul reached Tyre, he found the disciples, implying a search for them. By the Spirit, these disciples cautioned Paul not to go to Jerusalem, but duty called louder than the warning. Paul's unwavering resolve and determination to fulfill his mission prevailed, even in the face of potential afflictions. The spirits of prophets are subject to prophets, meaning that the revelation from the Holy Spirit is influenced by one's own will and temperament, shaped by their capacities and resolves.

Upon arriving in Tyre, Paul diligently sought out the disciples, who warned him through the leading of the Spirit against going to Jerusalem. However, Paul's unwavering commitment to duty overshadowed the cautionary message. He recognized that the revelation from the Holy Spirit is subject to one's own will and temperament, shaped by their capacities and resolves. With characteristic zeal, Paul pressed forward, bound by the leading of God, despite the potential afflictions that awaited him in Jerusalem.

When Paul arrived in Tyre, he diligently searched for the disciples he had previously preached to, finding them and staying with them for seven days. These disciples, speaking through the Spirit, warned Paul not to go up to Jerusalem, foretelling the afflictions that awaited him there. However, duty called louder than the warning, and Paul's unwavering determination to fulfill his mission prevailed. Even though the prophetic impulse of the disciples suggested that Paul could avoid danger by not going, he chose to press on, steadfast in his resolve.

When Paul arrived in Tyre, he diligently searched for the disciples he had previously preached to. The disciples warned Paul, through the leading of the Spirit, not to go up to Jerusalem due to the afflictions that awaited him there. Despite the cautionary message, Paul's unwavering determination to fulfill his mission prevailed. Even though the prophetic impulse suggested that Paul could avoid danger by not going, he pressed on steadfastly, bound by the leading of God.
